}} 'Vaccination' is the administration of antigenic material (a vaccine) to
stimulate an individual's immune system to develop adaptive immunity to a
pathogen. Vaccines can prevent or ameliorate morbidity from infection. The
effectiveness of vaccination has been widely studied and verified; for example,
the influenza vaccine, the HPV vaccine, and the chicken
pox vaccine. Vaccination is the most effective method of preventing
infectious diseases; *United States Centers for Disease Control and
Prevention (2011). [http://www.cdc.gov/oid/docs/ID-Framework.pdf A CDC
framework for preventing infectious diseases.] Accessed 11 September 2012.
âVaccines are our most effective and cost-saving tools for disease prevention,
preventing untold suffering and saving tens of thousands of lives and billions
of dollars in healthcare costs each year.â *American Medical Association
(2000). [http://www.immunizationinfo.org/es/pressroom/2000-06-01/vaccines-and-
infectious-diseases-putting-risk-perspective Vaccines and infectious diseases:
putting risk into perspective.] Accessed 11 September 2012. âVaccines are the
most effective public health tool ever created.â *Public Health Agency of
Canada. [http://www.phac-aspc.gc.ca/im/vpd-mev/index-eng.php Vaccine-
preventable diseases.] Accessed 11 September 2012. âVaccines still provide the
most effective, longest-lasting method of preventing infectious diseases in all
age groups.â *United States National Institute of Allergy and Infectious
Diseases (NIAID). [http://virtualbiosecuritycenter.org/wp-content/uploads/2012/01/Library-NIAID-
Biodefense-Research-Agenda-for-Category-B-and-C-Priority-Pathogens.pdf NIAID
Biodefense Research Agenda for Category B and C Priority Pathogens.] Accessed
11 September 2012. âVaccines are the most effective method of protecting the
public against infectious diseases.â widespread immunity due to
vaccination is largely responsible for the worldwide eradication of smallpox
and the restriction of diseases such as polio, measles, and tetanus from much
of the world.

The active agent of a vaccine may be intact but inactivated (non-infective) or
attenuated (with reduced infectivity) forms of the causative pathogens, or
purified components of the pathogen that have been found to be highly
immunogenic (e.g., outer coat proteins of a virus). Toxoids are produced for
immunization against toxin-based diseases, such as the modification of
tetanospasmin toxin of tetanus to remove its toxic effect but retain its
immunogenic effect. http://www.cdc.gov/vaccines/pubs/pinkbook/downloads/tet-
anus.pdf

Smallpox was likely the first disease people tried to prevent by purposely
inoculating themselves with other infections and was the first disease for which a vaccine was
produced. The smallpox vaccine was designed in 1796 by the British physician
Edward Jenner, although at least six people had used the same principles several
years earlier. Louis Pasteur furthered the concept
through his pioneering work in microbiology. The immunization was called
vaccination because it was derived from a virus affecting cows ()(). Smallpox was a contagious and deadly
disease, causing the deaths of 20â60% of infected adults and over 80% of
infected children. When smallpox was finally eradicated in 1979,
during the 20th century alone it had killed an estimated 300â500 million people-
. [http://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2008/01/08013-
1122956.htm How Poxviruses Such As Smallpox Evade The Immune System],
ScienceDaily, February 1, 2008

In common speech, 'vaccination' and 'immunization' have a similar meaning. This
distinguishes it from inoculation, which uses unweakened live pathogens,
although in common usage either is used to refer to an immunization. Vaccination
efforts have been met with some controversy since their inception, on
scientific, ethical, political, medical safety, and religious grounds. In rare
cases, vaccinations can injure people and, in the United States, they may
receive compensation for those injuries under the National Vaccine Injury
Compensation Program. Early success and compulsion brought widespread
acceptance, and mass vaccination campaigns have greatly reduced the incidence of
many diseases in numerous geographic regions.
